Detailed Description

class must be constructed in your activate function in order for any globals derived from this class to work. It can be constructed as an automatic variable, or on the heap. Because the working values are static, they survive destruction

Member Function Documentation

int lwpp::LWPPInterfaceInfo::alertLevel (   )  [inline]
 

alertLevel - returns one of the following: LWALERT_BEGINNER 0 LWALERT_INTERMEDIATE 1 LWALERT_EXPERT 2 Added in version 7 Returns -1 in case of a BAD_GLOBAL Tested OK

unsigned long lwpp::LWPPGlobal::application (   )  [inline, inherited]
 

application - possible return values are

  • LWSYS_LAYOUT
  • LWSYS_MODELER
  • LWSYS_SCREAMERNET Tested OK

Because LWSYS_ constants are before the value is shifted right I'm returning the value unshifted. User friendly functions should be added.

int lwpp::LWPPInterfaceInfo::autoKeyCreate (   )  [inline]
 

autoKeyCreate - returns one of the following: LWAKC_OFF 0 LWAKC_MODIFIED 1 LWAKC_ALL 2 Added in version 7.5 ??? Returns -1 in case of a BAD_GLOBAL

NOTICE the use of the build() function to prevent crashes when working in 7.5b or less. Support for this member may have existed before 7.5c ... if you know when it was added, please report that to LightWrap++

int lwpp::LWPPInterfaceInfo::boxThreshold (   )  [inline]
 

boxThreshold - returns the number of points above which, an item will be displayed as a bounding box. Added in version 7 Returns -1 in case of a BAD_GLOBAL

unsigned long lwpp::LWPPGlobal::build (   )  [inline, inherited]
 

build - returns the Build number of the product.

Known build numbers Windows 7.5 - 572 7.5c - 584 7.5d - 598

If you know any build numbers for any platform which are not listed here, please report them to LightWrap++ Tested OK

unsigned int lwpp::LWPPInterfaceInfo::displayFlags (   )  [inline]
 

displayFlags - returns 0 or more of: LWDISPF_MOTIONPATHS (1<<0) LWDISPF_HANDLES (1<<1) LWDISPF_IKCHAINS (1<<2) LWDISPF_CAGES (1<<3) LWDISPF_SAFEAREAS (1<<4) LWDISPF_FIELDCHART (1<<5)

In case of BAD_GLOBAL returns 0xdeadbeef

unsigned int lwpp::LWPPInterfaceInfo::generalFlags (   )  [inline]
 

generalFlags - returns 0 or more of the following: LWGENF_HIDETOOLBAR (1<<0) LWGENF_RIGHTTOOLBAR (1<<1) LWGENF_PARENTINPLACE (1<<2) LWGENF_FRACTIONALFRAME (1<<3) LWGENF_KEYSINSLIDER (1<<4) LWGENF_PLAYEXACTRATE (1<<5) LWGENF_AUTOKEY (1<<6) In case of BAD_GLOBAL returns 0xdeadbeef

int lwpp::LWPPInterfaceInfo::itemColor (  LWItemID  item  )  [inline]
 

itemColor - returns the color Layout uses to draw the chosen item. According to the SDK, there are 15 possible return values which are indexes into the array of colors that can be set in the spreadSheet Added in version 7 Returns -1 in case of a BAD_GLOBAL

unsigned int lwpp::LWPPInterfaceInfo::itemFlags (  LWItemID  item  )  [inline]
 

itemFlags - returns itemFlags associated with item. LWITEMF_SELECTED (1<<0) LWITEMF_SHOWCHILDREN (1<<1) LWITEMF_SHOWCHANNELS (1<<2) LWITEMF_LOCKED (1<<3) In case of BAD_GLOBAL returns 0xdeadbeef

int lwpp::LWPPInterfaceInfo::itemVis (  LWItemID  item  )  [inline]
 

itemVis - returns visibility flag for item. LWOVIS_HIDDEN 0 LWOVIS_BOUNDINGBOX 1 LWOVIS_VERTICES 2 LWOVIS_WIREFRAME 3 LWOVIS_FFWIREFRAME 4 LWOVIS_SHADED 5 LWOVIS_TEXTURED 6 some item types return LWIVIS_HIDDEN 0 LWIVIS_VISIBLE 1 Returns -1 in case of BAD_GLOBAL

unsigned long lwpp::LWPPGlobal::locale (   )  [inline, inherited]
 

locale - returns the language ID.

bool lwpp::LWPPGlobal::operator! (   )  [inline, inherited]
 

operator ! - A synonym for checking isValid() like this: LWPPGlobal myGlobal(global); if (!myGlobal) { return AFUNC_BADGLOBAL; }

Be aware that if you construct one of these on the heap you'll have to change the syntax accordingly. I'm thinking "if (! *myGlobal)", but I haven't tested this. Otherwise you're just checking for a non-NULL address, and not actually calling isValid().

Another alternative for heap based construction would be: if (myGlobal->operator !()) but from that, you see the following is cleaner syntax: if (! myGlobal->isValid()) Tested OK

revision - returns a user friendly string.

LWPPGlobal revision - returns a user friendly string. Tested OK

Tried using std::string, but got compiler errors when including stdlib.h. Because I needed ultoa more than I needed a string class, stdlib won out.

Member Data Documentation

GlobalFunc * lwpp::LWPPGlobal::GLOBAL = NULL [static, protected, inherited]
 

Wont link unless we set aside storage space for statics.

I made storage for these values static because it seems wasteful and useless for each global to have its own identical copy of these values that don't change during a session. Once the constructor is called, these values will live on, even after destruction.
